analysis.analysis: Positive signal: VN-Index slightly decreased with low liquidity, indicating limited selling pressure.
VN-Index experienced its first decline after four consecutive rising sessions, considered a normal technical adjustment.
VN-Index is likely to consolidate in the 1,260 - 1,270 point range before continuing the uptrend.
The number of declining stocks on HOSE outnumbered advancers, and foreign investors had a net sell of 88 billion VND, contributing to the market's decline pressure.
VN-Index closed down nearly 3 points due to increased selling pressure, portfolio restructuring, and the decline of large-cap stocks (VIC, VCB, BID).
Overall for the week, VN-Index increased by 3.34% compared to the previous week, closing at 1,267.30 points.
VN-Index closed at 1,269.80 points with a trading value of 19,113 billion VND.
VN-Index recorded the strongest weekly gain of 3.34%.
The rise after applying the KRX system aligns with expectations, but the market is nearing the 1,270 - 1,280 resistance zone, so investors should limit new purchases and consider taking profits.
EIB (Eximbank): Appointed 2 Deputy General Directors amid its transfer to the HoSE exchange.
PSH: HOSE will place PSH stock under supervision starting May 14, 2025.
Top-performing stocks in price strength are expected to outperform VN-Index in the next 1-2 weeks.
The short-term technical score for VN-Index is 4, indicating a 'Positive' outlook.
VN-Index is fluctuating around the 1,270 resistance level.
Overview of VN-Index, VN30 Index, VN70 Index, and VNFinLead Index including market cap and closing prices as of May 9, 2025.
As of May 9, 2025, VN-Index reached 1,545.69 points.
VN-Index charted against USD/VND exchange rate.
VN-Index P/E ratio compared with historical averages and standard deviations.
VN-Index valuation compared to the 10-year average P/E.
Resistance 1: 1,270; Resistance 2: 1,280; Support 1: 1,180; Support 2: 1,140.
VN-Index closed at 1,267 points, down 2.5 points (-0.2%) due to increased afternoon selling pressure.
VN-Index rose 3.34% in a week, 15.81% in a month, and 0.04% year-to-date, closing at 1,267.3 on May 9.
VN-Index closed at 1,267.30 on May 9 with a weekly change of 3.34% and a year-to-date change of 0.04%.
HOSE index rose 3.3% to 1,267.30.
Average trading volume on HOSE increased by 1.2%, while trading value decreased by 0.9%.
Maintaining low selling pressure helps reduce the risk of a bull trap and supports recovery to the 1,300-1,310 point range.
Comparison of P/E, P/B, ROE, ROA, market cap, average trading value, and net foreign purchases YTD among Vietnam (VN-Index), Thailand (SET Index), Indonesia (JCI Index), and the Philippines (PCOMP).
Chart of 20-day cumulative net foreign trading value on HSX, HNX, and UPCOM.
Table of 15 stocks contributing to VN-Index, including price, price change, market cap, index impact, EPS, PB, PE, and trend indicators.
VN-Index is expected to reach 1,270-1,275 points tomorrow but may face selling pressure after four consecutive gains.
VN-Index: 34% of stocks above 50-day MA, 66% below; 73% above 20-day MA, 27% below.
Intraday support is in the 1,260-1,263 point range.
VN-Index fell 0.2% to 1,267.3 with 130 gainers, 173 losers, and 58 unchanged; liquidity reached 666.4 million USD.
VN-Index declined 2.5 points to 1,267.3.
VN-Index fell after four days of gains due to high-price selling pressure on HOSE; VN30 showed a similar trend.

Top contributing sectors to VN-Index include Real Estate, Banking, Chemicals, IT, Food & Beverage, Financial Services, Oil & Gas, Basic Resources, Utilities, Construction & Materials, Healthcare, Insurance, Retail, Tourism & Entertainment.
VN-Index movement is calculated from the recommendation date to the closing date to assess recommendation effectiveness.
VN-Index increased by 1.55%, YTD +0.24%.
Investors can use trailing stop or partial sales during recovery phases near the 1,270-1,280 resistance zone to restructure or take profits.
VN-Index rose for the fourth consecutive session and closed around 1,270; short-term reactions at the 1,270-1,280 resistance zone should be monitored to confirm a sustainable mid-term trend.
VN-Index dropped 0.20% to 1,267.30 while VN30 rose 0.09% to 1,352.35; market breadth tilted toward sellers with 136 gainers and 174 losers.
VN-Index closed near 1,270 points with increased liquidity, led by real estate, tech, and financial stocks, while mid- and small-cap stocks showed divergence.
VN-Index is expected to fluctuate around 1,265-1,275 points, with large-cap stocks playing a key role in index movement.

AI_News.title: Ukraine continues drone attacks on Moscow ahead of Victory Day
AI_News.summary: Russia's capital shook for the third consecutive day as Ukraine launched a series of drone (UAV) attacks just ahead of Victory Day, causing several airports to temporarily halt operations. The attacks occurred on the eve of multiple world leaders arriving in Russia and just two days before the military parade celebrating the 80th anniversary of the victory over Nazi Germany. Between 10 p.m. on May 6 and early morning on May 7, Russian air defenses intercepted at least 14 Ukrainian drones en route to the capital. Airports were disrupted and airlines scrambled to adjust schedules. On May 5, fighter jets flew over Red Square in Moscow as part of a parade rehearsal. Photo: Xinhua. Chinese President Xi Jinping is expected to arrive in Moscow on the evening of May 7 and attend the Red Square parade on May 9, along with 28 other leaders from Asia, Africa, Latin America, and several European countries. According to the Kremlin, leaders attending are from: Abkhazia, Armenia, Azerbaijan, Belarus, Bosnia and Herzegovina, Brazil, Burkina Faso, Congo, Cuba, Egypt, Equatorial Guinea, Ethiopia, Guinea-Bissau, Kazakhstan, Kyrgyzstan, Laos, Mongolia, Myanmar, Palestine, Serbia, Slovakia, South Ossetia, Tajikistan, Turkmenistan, Uzbekistan, Venezuela, Vietnam, and Zimbabwe. Xi is expected to sign several strategic agreements during the visit. He previously called for negotiations to end the Ukraine crisis and blamed the U.S. for escalating the situation by providing arms to Kyiv. In a May 7 op-ed in Russian media, Xi emphasized that China and Russia must 'safeguard the post-WWII international order' and resist any attempts to divide the two nations.
